Ricky Glaser (@rickyglaser) regularly skates the many (skate) parks of his native Melbourne, but he loves to skate out in the streets, too. â€œFinding obstacles not designed for skating on can be a fun challenge and spark new creative ideas,â€ says the 28-year-old professional skateboarder, who has been skating since the age of 8. â€œWhen youâ€™ve skated for as long as I have and have done so many different tricks, it can be fun to completely change your approach with an external prop like a skipping rope,â€ he says. ğŸ›¹#ThisWeekOnInstagram â£ â£

â€œI feel like being a Black man in America, there are a lot of expectations that are put on you. Expectations about the way you should act in public, the way you should express your sexuality, the way you should dress â€” and it can often be a lot of pressure,â€ says 21-year-old photographer, director and student Myles Loftin. â£
â£
â€œBut I also think that being a Black man in America means that thereâ€™s a lot of possibility. At least right now Iâ€™m seeing a lot of possibility for myself and for the members of my community to exist freely. And I feel like weâ€™re really taking advantage of that right now in a really positive way.â€â£
â£
This Black History Month weâ€™ve partnered with @bet to #ShareBlackStories and support #Advocates doing amazing work on Instagram and beyond. To learn more about Myles, watch our latest episode.

Meet 21-year-old photographer and director Myles Loftin (@mylesloftin), an advocate for sharing stories of underrepresented communities and stories. â€œProbably more often than not I would say that I felt like an outsider in spaces. And I guess maybe thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m so passionate about making sure that people feel seen, because I know what it feels like to not be seen and to not feel comfortable in a space,â€ says the Parsons School of Design student.â£
â£
â€œI #ShareBlackStories through my photography, making sure to highlight the Black community as much as I can,â€ says Myles. â€œAlso just through me existing. I am a Black story walking.â€â£
â£
This Black History Month, weâ€™ve partnered with @bet to #ShareBlackStories and support #Advocates doing amazing work on Instagram and beyond. New episodes drop every Tuesday in February. ğŸ–¤â£

For professional scooter rider Vincent Kudrna (@vincentkudrna), scootering is liberating. â€œI donâ€™t have any coaches telling me what to do or where I need to be. What I do on a scooter is truly all up to me,â€ says the San Diego native. â€œI really connected with scootering because it combines all the best aspects of other action sports. You can grind like a skateboarder with the deck, do tail whips and bar spins like a BMX biker, and you can spin and move quickly like a Rollerblader,â€ he says. #ThisWeekOnInstagramâ£
